We determine all complex K3 surfaces with Picard rank 20 over [MATH_0] . Here the N\'eron-Severi group has rank 20 and is generated by divisors which are defined over [MATH_1] . Our proof uses modularity, the Artin-Tate conjecture and class group theory. With different techniques, the result has been established by Elkies to show that Mordell-Weil rank 18 over [MATH_2] is impossible for an elliptic K3 surface. We then apply our methods to general singular K3 surfaces, i.e.~with N\'eron-Severi group of rank 20, but not necessarily generated by divisors over [MATH_3] .
Singular K3 surface, Artin-Tate conjecture, complex multiplication, modular form, class group

Complex K3 surfaces of geometric Picard number 20 are called singular since they involve no moduli. They share many properties with elliptic curves with complex multiplication (CM). For instance, they can always be defined over some number field. Moreover, over some finite extension of the number field, the [MATH_4] -series is given in terms of Hecke characters (cf.~Theorem~ Thm:SI ).

For singular K3 surfaces over [MATH_5] , Livn\'e proved the motivic modularity in L . However, this definition does not require that the N\'eron-Severi group is generated by divisors which are defined over [MATH_6] . We refer to this particular property as ''Picard rank 20 over [MATH_7] ".

The motivation to study such K3 surfaces was the following: In Shioda-20 , Shioda raised the question whether it was possible for an elliptic K3 surface to have Mordell-Weil rank 18 over [MATH_8] . One way to disprove this would have been to show that in general, K3 surfaces with Picard rank 20 over [MATH_9] do not exist.
However, it turned out that there are such examples (see Examples Ex:19 , Ex:7 ). Recently Elkies determined all these surfaces in terms of their transcendental lattices:
Theorem [Elkies Elkies ] thm Let [MATH_10] be a K3 surface with Picard rank 20 over [MATH_11] . Then the transcendental lattice [MATH_12] is primitive of class number one. Theorem
Using sphere packings and gluing up to a Niemeier lattice, Elkies concluded that Mordell-Weil rank 18 over [MATH_13] is impossible for an elliptic K3 surface.

Conversely, let [MATH_14] be primitive of class number one. Then the singular K3 surface [MATH_15] with transcendental lattice [MATH_16] has a model with Picard rank 20 over [MATH_17] (cf.~section~ s:existence ).

In this paper, we present an alternative proof of Theorem~ thm that we hope to be of independent interest. Our proof uses the following ingredients: modularity plus the classification of CM-forms in S-CM ; reduction and the Artin-Tate conjecture at split primes; class group theory.
We then generalise our techniques to all singular K3 surfaces. We deduce the following obstruction to the field of definition:

Theorem thm:2 Let [MATH_18] be a number field and [MATH_19] a K3 surface of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_20] . Denote the discriminant of [MATH_21] by [MATH_22] . Then [MATH_23] contains the ring class field [MATH_24] . Theorem

This result enables us to give a direct proof of Safarevi c' finiteness theorem for singular K3 surfaces (Theorem~ Thm:oo ). It is the only known obstruction for the field of definition of a singular K3 surface other than the result on the genus of [MATH_25] in S-fields (cf.~( eq:Cl ) and Lemma~ Lem:2 ). In a private correspondence, Elkies informed the author that his proof for Theorem~ thm also generalises to Theorem~ thm:2 .

The paper is organised as follows: The next two sections recall the relevant facts about singular K3 surfaces and modularity. In section s:Ex we give two explicit examples of K3 surfaces of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_26] . Section s:AT introduces the main techniques to be used, in particular the Artin-Tate conjecture. The proof of Theorem~ thm is presented in the sections s:K to s:prim . The converse statement of Theorem~ thm is covered in section s:existence . We continue with the classification of K3 surfaces of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_27] up to [MATH_28] -isomorphism. Section s:quad generalises Theorem~ thm to K3 surfaces with Picard rank 20 over a quadratic extension of [MATH_29] . The paper concludes with the proof of the general case of Theorem~ thm:2 .

The main invariant of a singular K3 surface [MATH_30] is its transcendental lattice [MATH_31] . Here we consider the N\'eron-Severi group [MATH_32] of divisors up to algebraic equivalence as a lattice in [MATH_33] with cup-product. Then the transcendental lattice is the orthogonal complement [MATH_34] The following classification was first stated by Pjatecki - Sapiro and Safarevi c PSS . The proof was completed by Shioda and Inose SI :

Theorem [Pjatecki - Sapiro - Safarevi c, Shioda - Inose] Thm:Torelli The map [MATH_35] gives a bijection [MATH_36] Theorem The injectivity of this map follows from the Torelli theorem for singular K3 surfaces PSS . For the surjectivity, Shioda-Inose exhibited an explicit construction involving isogenous CM-elliptic curves [MATH_37] SI . This is often referred to as Shioda-Inose structure:

Here both rational maps are 2:1, and [MATH_39] . Shioda-Inose exhibited the rational map [MATH_40] through base change of elliptic fibrations. Explicit equations were subsequently given by Inose in Inose . In S-fields , Inose's results were improved to derive a model over the ring class field [MATH_41] associated to the discriminant [MATH_42] of the transcendental lattice (cf.~Lemma~ Lem:def ). Over some extension, one can moreover determine the [MATH_43] -function of [MATH_44] (Theorem~ Thm:SI ).

The set of singular K3 surfaces over [MATH_45] (up to [MATH_46] -isomorphism) is finite by a result of Safarevi c Shafa (cf.~Theorem~ Thm:oo ). However, there is only one effective obstruction known for a singular K3 surface [MATH_47] to be defined over [MATH_48] : By S-fields , the genus of [MATH_49] has to consist of a single class. (In Shimada , Shimada proved this first for the case of fundamental discriminant [MATH_50] .) In other words, we require that its class group is only two-torsion: [MATH_720] The general case will be treated in section~ s:gen . There we will also provide a formulation in terms of fields of definition (Lemma~ Lem:2 ).

The only drawback of relation ( eq:Cl ) is that the class group [MATH_51] does not recognise whether [MATH_52] is primitive. We know 101 discriminants [MATH_53] such that the class group [MATH_54] is only two-torsion. By a result of Weinberger Wb there is at most one more such [MATH_55] , and in fact none under some condition on Siegel-Landau zeroes (which would follow from GRH). However, so far we lacked bounds for the degree of primitivity of [MATH_56] . For Picard rank 20 over [MATH_57] , primitivity is part of Theorem~ thm . For the general case, bounds for the degree of primitivity follow from Theorem~ thm:2 (cf.~section~ s:gen ).
Modularity of singular K3 surfaces over [MATH_58]

We shall now see that condition ( eq:Cl ) can also be understood in terms of modularity. Here the modular motive is the compatible system of Galois representations attached to the transcendental lattice. Over some extension, this motive is related to Hecke characters by Theorem~ Thm:SI .

K3 surfaces of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_137] : Examples s:Ex

In this section, we recall two of the most elementary examples of K3 surfaces of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_138] . Both use elliptic fibrations with section. For further examples, the reader is referred to section s:existence .

Example Ex:19 There is a unique complex elliptic K3 surface [MATH_139] with a fibre of type [MATH_140] . The fibration can be defined over [MATH_141] . This follows from work of Hall Hall and was studied in detail by Shioda in ShCR . A simple explicit Weierstrass equation is derived in SS2 : [MATH_723]

Let [MATH_142] denote the hyperbolic plane generated by a general fibre and the zero-section. It is immediate that the N\'eron-Severi lattice of [MATH_143] (over [MATH_144] ) can be written as [MATH_145] In particular, [MATH_146] is a singular K3 surface. The Picard rank of [MATH_147] over [MATH_148] is 20 if and only if the all components of the special fibre are defined over [MATH_149] (i.e.~the special fibre has split multiplicative reduction). This can be achieved by an appropriate twist as in ( eq:twist ) and was first exhibited in ST . The model in ( eq:19 ) has the fibre of type [MATH_150] at [MATH_151] . The fibre is split multiplicative, so the Picard rank of the surface over [MATH_152] is already 20. The corresponding Hecke eigenform has level [MATH_153] by ST (see [Table 1] S-CM ). Example
The next example goes back to Tate Tate-AEC . It has been studied very concretely by Hulek and Verrill in HV .

Example Ex:7 Let [MATH_154] denote the universal elliptic curve for [MATH_155] . Since this group has genus 0, the base curve is [MATH_156] . One the other hand, the space of cusp forms [MATH_157] is one-dimensional, so [MATH_158] has geometric genus [MATH_159] . It follows that [MATH_160] is a K3 surface. By general theory, the elliptic surface [MATH_161] has a model over [MATH_162] with a section [MATH_163] of order 7 also defined over [MATH_164] . Such a model was first given by Tate in Tate-AEC : [MATH_165] Here [MATH_166] is a point of order 7. In the following, we shall employ an abstract approach to show that [MATH_167] has Picard rank 20 over [MATH_168] .

The quotient of [MATH_169] by translation by [MATH_170] gives rise to another elliptic K3 surface after resolving singularities. Hence the configuration of singular fibres can only be [1,1,1,7,7,7]. In particular, [MATH_171] is a singular K3 surface. We claim that the above model has Picard rank 20 over [MATH_172] . Equivalently, each reducible fibre is completely defined over [MATH_173] . To prove this, we show that [MATH_174] meets each [MATH_175] fibre in a different non-trivial component.

We employ Shioda's theory of Mordell-Weil lattices and the height pairing ShMW . As a torsion section, [MATH_176] has height 0. Since [MATH_177] does not meet the 0-section, we can compute the height directly as [MATH_178] Here the correction terms are [MATH_179] according to the component [MATH_180] which [MATH_181] meets (cyclically numbered so that the zero-section meets [MATH_182] ). The only way to obtain [MATH_183] is [MATH_184] Since [MATH_185] intersects each [MATH_186] fibre at a non-trivial component, these special fibres are split multiplicative. Moreover, as the components differ for each [MATH_187] fibre, their cusps cannot be conjugate. Hence all fibre components are defined over [MATH_188] , and the claim follows. Example

Remark Rem:EMS The same argument applies to other modular elliptic K3 surfaces, but not to all of them. For instance, the universal elliptic curve for [MATH_189] is a Kummer surface. Hence it cannot have Picard rank 20 over [MATH_190] by the next remark. This argument will also be used in the proof of the primitivity of the transcendental lattice (Lemma~ Lem:prim ). Alternatively, we could also argue with the Weil pairing. Since the Weil pairing has image [MATH_191] , the fourth roots of unity, we deduce that [MATH_192] . Then we apply the inverse argument of Example~ Ex:7 to a 4-torsion section which is not defined over [MATH_193] . This implies that there are singular fibres which are not completely defined over [MATH_194] . Remark

Let [MATH_200] be a K3 surface of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_201] . In order to prove Theorem~ thm , we will consider the reductions of [MATH_202] at the good primes [MATH_203] that split in [MATH_204] and apply the Artin-Tate Conjecture.

Existence of K3 surfaces of Picard rank 20 over [MATH_468] s:existence

There are 13 primitive lattices [MATH_469] of class number one appearing in Theorem~ thm . For each of them one can ask whether there is a K3 surface with Picard rank 20 over [MATH_470] and this transcendental lattice. Elkies announced in Elkies that this holds true for each [MATH_471] . It follows that for each of these surfaces, one such model is given by Inose's fibration for the CM-elliptic curve corresponding to [MATH_472] , as exhibited over [MATH_473] in S-fields .

However, for Inose's fibration, the non-trivial sections are often not immediate. In the cases at hand, there are two fibres of type [MATH_474] plus an additional reducible fibre of type [MATH_475] . Hence the Mordell-Weil rank is one. Elkies recently computed the Mordell-Weil generator of height [MATH_476] explicitly for all these fibrations E-web .

For the reader's convenience we include a list of different models of these K3 surfaces where the Picard rank 20 over [MATH_477] becomes evident. These models are given in terms of elliptic fibrations with configuration of singular fibres and the abstract structure of the Mordell-Weil group. We also include a reference, but naturally the given models are far from unique. Other models may be found in Noam , S-Rocky , TY for instance. Explanations follow the table.

Singular K3 surfaces over number fields s:gen

We conclude the paper with an application of our techniques to general singular K3 surfaces. We will derive an explicit obstruction for the field of definition of the surface resp.~its N\'eron-Severi group. First we recall a possible field of definition:

Since there are only limited possibilities for the Galois action on the N\'eron-Severi lattice of a singular K3 surface (or on any lattice of given rank), Theorem~ thm:2 provides us with a direct proof of the following finiteness result due to Safarevi c.
